title: Implement showFirstIndentGuideLines

Adding showFirstIndentGuideLines to tweak UI experience (Current problem: if the following characters are a space, the Guide line continues until the next line with a character )

boolean: first indent guide lines

title: Link in the editor with the `vscode:` URI scheme is parsed as `file://vscode:...`
body:
Issue Type: Bug Cmd-clicking a link in the editor with the `vscode:extension/...` URI scheme + path doesn't launch the extension page, and results in an error. It seems that the URL opener service is not recognizing the `vscode:` URI scheme, and instead is assuming the link is a `file://` URI. Might be related to #69998. Discovered while fixing #71414. ## Steps to reproduce Create a Markdown file that contains a link with the `vscode:` URI scheme: ``` [Link to Python extension for vscode](vscode:extension/ms-python.python) ``` Cmd-click link in editor. Receive error: > Unable to open 'ms-python.python': File not found (file:///vscode:extension/ms-python.python). Expected behavior is to launch the extension page for `extension/ms-python.python`. VS Code version: Code 1.32.3 (a3db5be9b5c6ba46bb7555ec5d60178ecc2eaae4, 2019-03-14T22:46:48.547Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.0.0

title: Passing ${workspaceFolder} to extension development host has no effect
body:
Version: 1.33.0-insider (user setup)
Commit: 0ac111466ec925fd5ca180ab9893f51531e419b2
Date: 2019-04-01T15:51:40.913Z
Electron: 3.1.6
Chrome: 66.0.3359.181
Node.js: 10.2.0
V8: 6.6.346.32
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new extension `yo code`
2. Change `launch.json` and include `"${workspaceFolder}"` as the first item in each `args` list.

**Expected behavior**: The workspace opened in the original instance to be also opened in the extension development host instance.

**Actual behavior**: The EDH opens without an active workspace.

I'm building an extension that, during tests, I need an active workspace. Not to repeat myself, here's my [SO question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55456193/testing-a-vscode-extension-that-involves-opening-a-folder-workspace/55469250#55469250).
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Example project that exhibits the issue: 
[hello-world.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/3035203/hello-world.zip)

title: WebviewPanel.reveal won't reveals to `SIDE_GROUP` if the specified group does not exist
body:
* Existing issues searched: true
* Tested under insider edition: true
* Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: true
- VS Code version: Code 1.32.3 (a3db5be9b5c6ba46bb7555ec5d60178ecc2eaae4, 2019-03-14T23:43:35.476Z)
- OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

## Bug Report
### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a webview panel with `viewColumn` set to One
2. Call `reveal` on the panel with `viewColumn` set to Two (not exists yet)
3. The panel only reveals to Column One.

### Workaround to make it right
1. Create a webview panel with `viewColumn` set to One
2. **Execute `workbench.action.focusSecondEditorGroup` command to ensure Group Two exists**
3. Call `reveal` on the panel with `viewColumn` set to Two (exists now)
4. The panel reveals to Column Two.

## Contrast Example

### showTextDocument
Designed behavior
* When clicking `Code Now`, a doc will be called by `showTextDocument` in Column 3.

 ![demo2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20227484/55531360-8d01a580-56dc-11e9-8f16-85206227a6d1.gif)
So:
  1. If I have 3 Columns, then doc will be open in Column 3.
  2. If I have 2 Columns, but Column 2 is empty, the doc will be open in Column 2.
  3. If I have 1 non-empty Column, then doc will be open in Column 2.

  This behavior is as by design.

### reveal
Designed behavior
* When **creating the webview**, the panel will be called by `reveal` to **Column 3**.
* When **clicking `Code Now`**, the panel will be called by `reveal`  to **Column 2**.

 ![demo1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20227484/55424235-5def1500-55b2-11e9-84d3-4bf55879a8a4.gif)
↑ Here, if all 3 columns exists, the panel will be created to Column 3 and moved to Column 2, as by design.  

 ![demo2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20227484/55424239-5e87ab80-55b2-11e9-9005-dca3286d7492.gif)
↑ Here, what happened?:
  1. If I have 2 **non-empty** Columns, and creating a new webview, the panel get revealed to **Column 2**, which **should have been in Column 3**.
  2. If I have 2 **non-empty** Columns, and clicking `Code Now`, the panel get revealed to **Column 2**, which is as by design.
  3. If I have 1 **non-empty** Columns, and creating a new webview, the panel get revealed to **Column 1**, which **should have been in Column 2**.
  4. If I have 1 **non-empty** Columns, and clicking `Code Now`, the panel get revealed to **Column 1**, which **should have been in Column 2**.

> we only allow revealing text documents in the group one greater than the current number of groups.

So, for `WebviewPanel.reveal`, it's not `one greater than`, it's `equal to`,  which is not by design.

title: Please add the 996.ICU license, thanks
body:
Repo: https://github.com/996icu/996.ICU

License: https://github.com/996icu/996.ICU/blob/master/LICENSE

# 996.ICU

- The name 996.ICU refers to **"Work by '996', sick in ICU"**, an ironic saying among Chinese programmers, which means that by following the "996" work schedule, you are risking yourself getting into the ICU (Intensive Care Unit).

# Principles and purposes

- 996.ICU is an initiative initiated by IT practitioners. We welcome people from other fields and other countries to join the discussion.

- This is not a political movement. We firmly uphold the labor law and require employers to respect the legitimate rights and interests of their employees.

- It is a great progress from closed source to open source, and it will also be a great progress from open source to emphasize labor rights at the same time. What we want is to create an open source software license that advocates for workers' rights.

- We are willing to hear all positive and constructive proposals and advocate for mature and responsible speech.

- We are working on the drafting of Anti-996 License right now and we hope to get help from professionals with relevant experience.

title: Showing the fixes menu (lightbulb) ends up saves the document

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Issue Type: Bug I don't believe this is new, but I think I have finally figured out an issue I've been having for a while now. The behavior I've been seeing is that using quick fixes to say add imports would sometimes completely screw up and insert imports in the middle of words, etc. I had always assumed that this was do to some timing conflict with applying the fix and my webpack watcher (which does linting fixes, including reordering imports), but until now I hadn't tracked down exactly how it happened. Today, I noticed that just showing the lightbulb quick fix menu (via shortcut key or using the mouse) causes the document to be saved -- this is because it is apparently considered to be a focus change as I have `"files.autoSave": "onFocusChange"` set. IMO this should not be considered a focus change. So because of this, changing focus to the menu, saves the document, which kicks off the watcher, while I then execute one of the fixes, which ends up applying a change to the document which might be a moving target because the webpack watcher is also mucking with it. Can we change the quick fix menu to not be considered a focus change of the document? VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.33.0-insider (0ac111466ec925fd5ca180ab9893f51531e419b2, 2019-04-01T15:51:40.913Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

title: vscode.debug.startDebugging returning undefined
body:
Issue Type: Bug `vscode.debug.startDebugging` is documented as returning `Thenable`. I'm trying to attach to Python code that has not reached its `ptvsd.enable_attach` statement yet (reference: [Python Debugging](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/python/debugging#_attach-to-a-local-script) ), and `vscode.debug.startDebugging` returns `undefined`. Is `undefined` a valid return value? If so, the documentation is incorrect. If not, I'm unclear how this happens. title: [scss] Validate scss @directives with `unknownProperties` rule

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Directives like `@tailwind` or `@apply` in the scss syntax get invalidated with a `css-rcurlyexpected` error. This means it is not possible to configure the syntax to stop validating these directives specifically. If directives were invalidated as `unknownProperties`, it would be possible to add them to the ignore list.

title: Handle source map/original file content diffs
body:
Often, when debugging js apps written in ts, I want to change the (ts) source code while debugging. This can be as subtle as adding single line comments, formatting the entire file or even changing statements or whole function bodies.

Then however, the js to ts source map is not valid anymore.
This is especially problematic when adding a single empty line at the top of the file - you have to restart the debugee so that nodejs catches up the new sourcemap.

It would be great if VSCode could create a new source map from the old ts source file (if the old content is embedded in the source map) to the new content (= the current editors content) and combine it with the existing source map. Code that could not be matched could be grayed out (e.g. changed statements and so on). Matching could be done on AST level.

Some remapping is actually done by vs code when adding lines before currently executed line. This remapping is however not persistent:
![demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2931520/55335768-03fc2b80-549c-11e9-831e-84f5e47fa0c8.gif)

title: Folder not removed after 'Path does not exist' dialog.
body:
[A gif of where the feature'll be.](https://i.imgur.com/RLGXHSK.gifv)

<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

Searched.

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

In Explorer, I move the folder to a different location.
I start VS Code up. I click on the folder name from 'Recent' in the quick start.
It says the path does not exist.
> I click the x that appears to the right of the folder after my mouse hovers over it.
The reference is removed.

Thanks in advance!

title: Automatically show changes side-by-side if there's only one group, otherwise show changes inline

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Please add an option to automatically show Git diff changes side-by-side, if there's only one group, and inline, if there's two or more groups. Since the side-by-side changes is too narrow if there are two or more groups, so I always manually change it anyway. But it would be very useful to have this automated.

title: Disable/Enable Emmet Command

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

title: Focus editor when using Find Widget
body:
After typing in the search field, pressing `enter`, `cmd + g`, or `cmd + shift +g` should focus the current editor that is being searched.

Currently, the Find Widget keeps the focus, so the user is required to put the focus back in the editor before they can update any text.

With this change, users can always put the focus back in the editor with `cmd + f`.

title: Task input parameters from showOpenDialog

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
It sure would be helpful if the task and launch input pickers implemented by #4758 were expanded to include one that wrapped the [`window.showOpenDialog` API](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#window) with its options for file vs. folder and filtering.


The [`window.showOpenDialog` API](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#window) offers to _extension authors_ the ability to offer the user a dialog to select a file (optionally with an extension filter) or a folder.

The feature available to _users_ is to be able to define  [input variables](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/variables-reference#_input-variables) for usage as task parameters. This user-facing feature only offers the ability to either select between preset strings (`pickString`) or accept a manually-typed input string (`promptString`), but offers no ability to present the user with a file or folder selection dialog.

This feature could be very helpful for users as well, not just extension authors. For example, I want to debug a program that supports command-line parameters for input files or directories, and I'd rather prompt the user to provide them differently for each session, than to have them hard-coded in a shared project tasks file.

title: API to trigger a refresh of the OUTLINE (DocumentSymbols)
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently `provideDocumentSymbols` is called whenever a documents content changes.  

There are occasions when the "known" list of symbols for a document may get updated independently to the document getting changed (like during a background compile, or a user initiated "check syntax").

It would be nice if we could trigger an event which would force a given document to request the latest list of known symbols from the DocumentSymbolProvider.

(its quite common for compilers to provide the outline quickly via a simplistic AST, but then "fill in the gaps" as part of a full compile).

title: Perl5 support to fold POD blocks
body:
Perl5 POD blocks (as defined with the =pod and =cut tags) should be foldable.
This documentation format is excessively verbose and clutters the file
when other sections are folded (especially after a "fold all"
operation).

This change allows top-level Perl5 POD documentation to be folded as well.

title: Add new remote option when publishing branch

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Added the ability to add a new remote when publishing a branch. Closes #71242. Here is an example of creating a new branch, selecting the publish branch command, and creating a new remote. The branch gets published to that new remote.

![publishBranch](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44308390/55209224-7a084600-51af-11e9-99f5-dd0b0f66c08d.gif)

I had a few questions about some ways to make the remote experience more consistent:
- Should the ability to add a remote be an option on the "Push to.." and "Pull from..." menus as well?
![Screenshot (19)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44308390/55209176-3ad9f500-51af-11e9-92b0-2995681e13c1.png)

- Should the remotes on the "Publish branch" command show the remote URL, like the  "Push to.." and "Pull from..." menus do?
![Screenshot (20)_LI](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44308390/55209196-593ff080-51af-11e9-8b07-58e952d55103.jpg)

title: Need keyboard shortcuts for buttons in custom dialog

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
In Mac OS you can press cmd+letter on many native prompts to select the option that starts with that letter. For example, I can press cmd+D to select "Don't Save". Would be great for my muscle memory to have this in the custom dialog too. Otherwise I have to count tabs carefully to hit the right button, or grab my mouse.

Similarly, some people will probably want the pneumonics that the windows native prompt has (like alt+n for "Don't Save").

title: Create new folder in simplified file dialog

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Maybe you've already thought about this but it would be useful to be able to create a new folder in the simplified file dialog. This could be a button in the title bar or a confirmation step when a folder that doesn't exist was typed.

Creating a folder and opening it, and creating a folder and saving a file in it, are common workflows so it would be useful to be able to do those in one step.

title: Add cmd + D to duplicate line in default keybindings
body:
Inbound feature request from NPS:

Add cmd + D to duplicate line in default keybindings

Related issues:
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/38875

title: Simple language agnostic code completion
body:
Feature request inbound from NPS feedback:

> "Offer simple language agnostic code completion like Sublime Text does. Also their "Jump to Definition" feature is incredibly useful and works with almost every language without installing any packages."

title: Verified extensions in marketplace
body:
Feature request from inbound NPS surveys:

> "Flag officially supported plugins similar to DockerHub's images."
		
> "Some functionality which should be integrated into the IDE is left to support of extensions, some of which are buggy, MS should review highly requested categories, and extensions to be rebuilt and folded into what would then be a superior offering."

**Inspiration:**
- Docker Hub, https://docs.docker.com/docker-hub/publish/trustchain/

title: Remove single line / group from debug console
body:
Hi all,

It would be very handy if I could take a line of debug console output and delete it.

For example, if you have lots of `log` / `printf` statements throughout an application to track how an object is manipulated from point to point (e.g. tracking changes in a Redux store or something similar), it would be very nice to be able to delete log lines pertaining to certain actions, or to remove them until you have a clear picture of what's going on.

Maybe it can be buried in a right click action on the line in question?

Other thoughts?
